item.title: Fix my CSS!
item.description:
Here is my CSS for my beastie web pages. I've removed the wide margins for narrow displays (phones). But I can't get chrome to wrap urls (see syllabus.html). Alternate browsers on my phone wrap properly...

Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated!


Code:
html
    {
    background-color: silver;
    border-left: 100px solid silver;
    border-right: 100px solid silver;
    border-top: 10px solid silver;
    }

body
    {
    font-size:100%;
    font-family: serif;
    background-color: FloralWhite;
    padding-top: 10px;
    padding-left: 40px;
    padding-right: 40px;
    padding-bottom: 30px;
    color:black;
    line-height: 1.3;
    }

#title { font-size: 150%;}

h1 {font-size:150%;}
h2 {font-size:120%;}
h3 {font-size:100%; font-weight: normal; }

h1, h2, h3 { margin-left:-20px; }

#title { color:#0F0F5F; }
h1 { color:#0F0F5F; }
h2 { color:#0F0F5F; }
h3 { color:#0F0F5F; }

a:link {color:red;text-decoration:none;}
a:visited {color:maroon;text-decoration:none;}
a:hover {color:red;font-weight:bold;text-decoration:underline;}

h2 a:link {color:darkslategray;text-decoration:none;}
h2 a:visited {color:darkslategray;text-decoration:none;}
h2 a:hover {color:darkslategray;font-weight:bold;text-decoration:none;}

code,tt,pre    { font-size: 110%; color: #115555; }

hr
    {
    margin-left: -20px;
    width: 100%;
    height: 4px;
    color:#AFCF9F;
    background-color:#AFCF9F;
    }

sub, sup { font-size: 75% }

p { line-height: 1.1; }
pre { line-height: 1.3; }
sub, sup { line-height: 0; }

.ldraw
    {
    margin-top: 15px;
    margin-left: 60px;
    }

center .ldraw
    {
    margin-top: 0px;
    margin-left: 0px;
    }

.smaller {font-size: smaller; }
.bigger {font-size: larger; }
.indent {
    margin-top: 0px;
    margin-bottom: 0px;
    padding-left: 40px;
    padding-bottom: 0px;
    display: block;
    }

ol ul {
    margin-left: 40px;
    margin-bottom: 10px;
    }
    
ol ol {
    margin-left: 40px;
    margin-bottom: 10px;
    }
    
li li {
    margin-top: 8px;
    }

li li > pre
    {
    margin-top: 10px;
    margin-bottom: 0px;
    padding-top: 0px;
    padding-bottom: 0px;
    }

table {
    padding-top: 10px;
    padding-bottom: 10px;
    padding-left: 10px;
    padding-right: 10px;
    }

table {    
    color:    black;
    text-decoration:    none;
    border-color:    black;
    border-style:    none;
    background: none;
    border-top: 1px solid darkgreen;
    border-bottom: 1px solid darkgreen;
    margin-top: 40px;
    /* border-collapse: collapse; */
    }    

tr, td {
    background-color: FloralWhite;
    }

td {padding-left: 10px; padding-right: 10px;
    vertical-align: center; }


@media screen and (max-width: 768px)
    {
    html
        {
        background-color: cyan;
        border-left: 0px solid cyan;
        border-right: 0px solid cyan;
        }

    body
        {
        font-family: serif;
        font-size:100%;
        background-color: FloralWhite;
        border: 1px solid silver;
        padding-top: 10px;
        padding-left: 2px;
        padding-right: 2px;
        padding-bottom: 30px;
        color:black;
        line-height: 1.3;
    word-wrap: break-word;
        }

    hr
        {
        margin-left: 2px;
        width: 95%;
        }

    
    h1, h2, h3 { margin-left: 0px; }

    ol {
        margin-left: -10px;
        }

    ol ul {
        margin-left: 0px;
        }
        
    ol ol {
        margin-left: 0px;
    }
    

    img
        {
        max-width:90%;
        height: auto;
        }
    }
item.content:encoded:
Here is my CSS for my beastie web pages. I've removed the wide margins for narrow displays (phones). But I can't get chrome to wrap urls (see syllabus.html). Alternate browsers on my phone wrap properly...

Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated!


Code:
html
    {
    background-color: silver;
    border-left: 100px solid silver;
    border-right: 100px solid silver;
    border-top: 10px solid silver;
    }

body
    {
    font-size:100%;
    font-family: serif;
    background-color: FloralWhite;
    padding-top: 10px;
    padding-left: 40px;
    padding-right: 40px;
    padding-bottom: 30px;
    color:black;
    line-height: 1.3;
    }

#title { font-size: 150%;}

h1 {font-size:150%;}
h2 {font-size:120%;}
h3 {font-size:100%; font-weight: normal; }

h1, h2, h3 { margin-left:-20px; }

#title { color:#0F0F5F; }
h1 { color:#0F0F5F; }
h2 { color:#0F0F5F; }
h3 { color:#0F0F5F; }

a:link {color:red;text-decoration:none;}
a:visited {color:maroon;text-decoration:none;}
a:hover {color:red;font-weight:bold;text-decoration:underline;}

h2 a:link {color:darkslategray;text-decoration:none;}
h2 a:visited {color:darkslategray;text-decoration:none;}
h2 a:hover {color:darkslategray;font-weight:bold;text-decoration:none;}

code,tt,pre    { font-size: 110%; color: #115555; }

hr
    {
    margin-left: -20px;
    width: 100%;
    height: 4px;
    color:#AFCF9F;
    background-color:#AFCF9F;
    }

sub, sup { font-size: 75% }

p { line-height: 1.1; }
pre { line-height: 1.3; }
sub, sup { line-height: 0; }

.ldraw
    {
    margin-top: 15px;
    margin-left: 60px;
    }

center .ldraw
    {
    margin-top: 0px;
    margin-left: 0px;
    }

.smaller {font-size: smaller; }
.bigger {font-size: larger; }
.indent {
    margin-top: 0px;
    margin-bottom: 0px;
    padding-left: 40px;
    padding-bottom: 0px;
    display: block;
    }

ol ul {
    margin-left: 40px;
    margin-bottom: 10px;
    }
    
ol ol {
    margin-left: 40px;
    margin-bottom: 10px;
    }
    
li li {
    margin-top: 8px;
    }

li li > pre
    {
    margin-top: 10px;
    margin-bottom: 0px;
    padding-top: 0px;
    padding-bottom: 0px;
    }

table {
    padding-top: 10px;
    padding-bottom: 10px;
    padding-left: 10px;
    padding-right: 10px;
    }

table {    
    color:    black;
    text-decoration:    none;
    border-color:    black;
    border-style:    none;
    background: none;
    border-top: 1px solid darkgreen;
    border-bottom: 1px solid darkgreen;
    margin-top: 40px;
    /* border-collapse: collapse; */
    }    

tr, td {
    background-color: FloralWhite;
    }

td {padding-left: 10px; padding-right: 10px;
    vertical-align: center; }


@media screen and (max-width: 768px)
    {
    html
        {
        background-color: cyan;
        border-left: 0px solid cyan;
        border-right: 0px solid cyan;
        }

    body
        {
        font-family: serif;
        font-size:100%;
        background-color: FloralWhite;
        border: 1px solid silver;
        padding-top: 10px;
        padding-left: 2px;
        padding-right: 2px;
        padding-bottom: 30px;
        color:black;
        line-height: 1.3;
    word-wrap: break-word;
        }

    hr
        {
        margin-left: 2px;
        width: 95%;
        }

    
    h1, h2, h3 { margin-left: 0px; }

    ol {
        margin-left: -10px;
        }

    ol ul {
        margin-left: 0px;
        }
        
    ol ol {
        margin-left: 0px;
    }
    

    img
        {
        max-width:90%;
        height: auto;
        }
    }

item.title: Out Friday Morning (September 28)
item.description: I'll be at the doctor's tomorrow (friday) morning. I should be back in the afternoon.
item.content:encoded: I'll be at the doctor's tomorrow (friday) morning. I should be back in the afternoon.

item.title: Accounts on Nixie
item.description:
Some of you have requested accounts on a linux server that has valgrind and gdb installed and working. That server is nixie.cs.ua.edu. Connect to nixie with the command:

ssh myNixieLogin@nixie.cs.ua.edu

Here is a script for uploading your project to nixie (replace my login name with yours):

Code:
#!/bin/bash
login=lusth
path=`pwd`
dir=`basename $path`
(cd ..; \
    tar cvfz project.tgz $dir; \
    cat project.tgz | ssh $login@nixie.cs.ua.edu "cat | tar xfvz -")


Name this file "push" and put it into your home directory's bin. Run chmod to make it executable:

chmod +x ~/bin/push

Then you can run push from your project directory. I HIGHLY suggest you setup passwordless logins to nixie. Don't come asking me for help on a nixie project without you doing this.

Also, use two windows, one on your development machine and one on nixie.
item.content:encoded:
Some of you have requested accounts on a linux server that has valgrind and gdb installed and working. That server is nixie.cs.ua.edu. Connect to nixie with the command:

ssh myNixieLogin@nixie.cs.ua.edu

Here is a script for uploading your project to nixie (replace my login name with yours):

Code:
#!/bin/bash
login=lusth
path=`pwd`
dir=`basename $path`
(cd ..; \
    tar cvfz project.tgz $dir; \
    cat project.tgz | ssh $login@nixie.cs.ua.edu "cat | tar xfvz -")


Name this file "push" and put it into your home directory's bin. Run chmod to make it executable:

chmod +x ~/bin/push

Then you can run push from your project directory. I HIGHLY suggest you setup passwordless logins to nixie. Don't come asking me for help on a nixie project without you doing this.

Also, use two windows, one on your development machine and one on nixie.

item.title: Resubmissions
item.description:
For resubmissions are we supposed to just submit to the same dropbox as the first submission aka submit ... assign0
or is there a new dropbox to submit to?
item.content:encoded:
For resubmissions are we supposed to just submit to the same dropbox as the first submission aka submit ... assign0

item.title: Simple mass tester makefile
item.description:
I saw @dawilly's tester that required some moving around of files everytime changes were made to the project code. So I came up with some simple makefile rules to run the tests. Just put all the test files and expected outputs (such as from submission0.tgz) in a subfolder called 'testing/' (you can change this TESTDIR value) under your main project folder and then add these rules (since I'm not allowed to post the whole makefile):

1. First define all the test file names under a variable (called TESTS here) near the top of your makefile. We can use a wildcard to get all the files under our testing directory:
Code:
TESTDIR = testing/
TESTS = $(sort $(basename $(notdir $(wildcard $(TESTDIR)*.c))))

2. Make sure your .h and .o files get copied to the testing directory when you compile them:
Code:
OBJS = integer.o real.o string.o da.o cda.o stack.o queue.o
all : $(OBJS)
    cp -f *.o $(TESTDIR)
    cp -f *.h $(TESTDIR)

Then we can add a rule for compiling our tests:
Code:
$(TESTS): %: $(TESTDIR)%.c all
    gcc -Wall -Wextra -g -o $(TESTDIR)$@ $< $(OBJS)

3. Define a simple for loop for running tests:
Code:
test : all $(TESTS)
    for x in $(TESTS); do \
        echo; echo -------; echo $$x.expected; echo -------; cat $(TESTDIR)$$x.expected; \
        ./$(TESTDIR)$$x > $(TESTDIR)$$x.yours; \
        echo -------; echo $$x.yours; echo -------; cat $(TESTDIR)$$x.yours; echo -------; \
        cmp --silent $(TESTDIR)$$x.expected $(TESTDIR)$$x.yours && echo "PASSED" || echo "FAILED"; echo -------; \
    done

4. Make a valgrind rule if your machine can handle it:
Code:
valgrind: all $(TESTS)
    for x in $(TESTS); do \
        valgrind --log-file=$(TESTDIR)$$x.valgrind $(TESTDIR)$$x; \
        echo; echo -------; echo $$x.valgrind; echo -------;  cat $(TESTDIR)$$x.valgrind; echo; \
    done


That should be all. After you make/build your main modules, you can literally just run make test and it'll run all the tests and do a diff on them too. You can pipe the output to a text file with something like
Code:
make test > output.txt
or
Code:
make valgrind > output.txt

This has been tested to work wonderfully with the submission0.tgz for assign0. The output.txt will contain all the tests that were defined in the TESTS variable. Doing a search for "FAILED" in the test output.txt will show all the tests that failed.

Feel free to change this as necessary (giving proper credit where due).
item.content:encoded:
I saw @dawilly's tester that required some moving around of files everytime changes were made to the project code. So I came up with some simple makefile rules to run the tests. Just put all the test files and expected outputs (such as from submission0.tgz) in a subfolder called 'testing/' (you can change this TESTDIR value) under your main project folder and then add these rules (since I'm not allowed to post the whole makefile):

1. First define all the test file names under a variable (called TESTS here) near the top of your makefile. We can use a wildcard to get all the files under our testing directory:
Code:
TESTDIR = testing/
TESTS = $(sort $(basename $(notdir $(wildcard $(TESTDIR)*.c))))

2. Make sure your .h and .o files get copied to the testing directory when you compile them:
Code:
OBJS = integer.o real.o string.o da.o cda.o stack.o queue.o
all : $(OBJS)
    cp -f *.o $(TESTDIR)
    cp -f *.h $(TESTDIR)

Then we can add a rule for compiling our tests:
Code:
$(TESTS): %: $(TESTDIR)%.c all
    gcc -Wall -Wextra -g -o $(TESTDIR)$@ $< $(OBJS)

3. Define a simple for loop for running tests:
Code:
test : all $(TESTS)
    for x in $(TESTS); do \
        echo; echo -------; echo $$x.expected; echo -------; cat $(TESTDIR)$$x.expected; \
        ./$(TESTDIR)$$x > $(TESTDIR)$$x.yours; \
        echo -------; echo $$x.yours; echo -------; cat $(TESTDIR)$$x.yours; echo -------; \
        cmp --silent $(TESTDIR)$$x.expected $(TESTDIR)$$x.yours && echo "PASSED" || echo "FAILED"; echo -------; \
    done

4. Make a valgrind rule if your machine can handle it:
Code:
valgrind: all $(TESTS)
    for x in $(TESTS); do \
        valgrind --log-file=$(TESTDIR)$$x.valgrind $(TESTDIR)$$x; \
        echo; echo -------; echo $$x.valgrind; echo -------;  cat $(TESTDIR)$$x.valgrind; echo; \
    done


That should be all. After you make/build your main modules, you can literally just run make test and it'll run all the tests and do a diff on them too. You can pipe the output to a text file with something like
Code:
make test > output.txt
or
Code:
make valgrind > output.txt

This has been tested to work wonderfully with the submission0.tgz for assign0. The output.txt will contain all the tests that were defined in the TESTS variable. Doing a search for "FAILED" in the test output.txt will show all the tests that failed.

Feel free to change this as necessary (giving proper credit where due).

item.title: Study group/partner
item.description: Hey, if anyone us interested in starting a study group please let me know. My study days would be Tue, Wed & Thur.
item.content:encoded: Hey, if anyone us interested in starting a study group please let me know. My study days would be Tue, Wed & Thur.

item.title: Class Location is HC 1026
item.description:
Just in case this confuses someone...

The remodeling done to H.M. Comer has changed the room numerical system. It is now a 4-digit number instead of a 3-digit number. Thus, CS 201 will be in HC 1026, not HC 126 (as it hasn't been updated in the class registration system yet). 

Is it the only classroom in H.M. Comer. Map provided below. It is far easier to find it if you just go through the side doors.
item.content:encoded:
Just in case this confuses someone...

The remodeling done to H.M. Comer has changed the room numerical system. It is now a 4-digit number instead of a 3-digit number. Thus, CS 201 will be in HC 1026, not HC 126 (as it hasn't been updated in the class registration system yet). 

Is it the only classroom in H.M. Comer. Map provided below. It is far easier to find it if you just go through the side doors.
